revisions.rev: {{lowercase|klik (packaging method)}} {{Lead too short|date=October 2009}} {{Infobox software | name = klik | logo = | screenshot = [[Image:Klik.png|150px|klik]] | caption = klik installing an application | collapsible = | author = | developer = [[Simon Peter (developer)|Simon Peter]] | released = | latest release version = 0.5r9 | latest release date = {{release date|2006|06|7}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | frequently updated = | programming language = | operating system = [[Linux]] | platform = | size = | language = | status = discontinued/unmaintained | genre = [[Software download system]] | license = [[GPL]] (client) | website = [http://web.archive.org/web/20070626012138/http://klik.atekon.de/ klik.atekon.de] (archived 2007) }} '''klik''' was a system for [[software]] [[download]] and usage on GNU/[[Linux]]. ==Technology== klik did not "install" software in the traditional sense (i.e., it did not put files all over the place in the system). It used one .cmg [[computer file|file]] per [[application software|application]]. Each one is self-contained: it includes all [[library (software)|libraries]] the application [[dependency (computer science)|depends]] on and that are not part of the base system. In this regard, it is similar to "[[application virtualization]]" or ''[[Portable application]]s''. One can ''klik'' a file even if they are not a [[superuser]], or they are using a [[live CD]]. klik integrated with web browsers on the user's computer. Users downloaded and installed software by typing a URL beginning with klik://. This downloaded a klik "recipe" file, which was used to generate the .cmg file. In this way, one recipe could be used to supply packages to a wide variety of platforms. klik files were often simpler than compiling and installing an application, as no installation actually took place. The .cmg file is a compressed image which is temporarily mounted to allow access to the program, but not having to extract the program or modify the underlying system. Currently only 8 klik programs can be run at once because of the limitation of mounting compressed images with the [[Linux kernel]], unless [[FUSE (Linux)|FUSE]] is used. The file is remounted each time the program is run, meaning the user can remove the program by simply deleting the .cmg file. ==Release history== klik was designed in 2004 by Simon Peter. A next version, klik2, was in development; and would natively incorporate the FUSE kernel module, but it never reached past the beta stage. Since 2011 the project homepage ''klik.atekon.de'' is not reachable anymore, but a successor project named ''PortableLinuxApps'' with similar goals was started by the main developer.{{cite web|url=http://portablelinuxapps.org/docs/1.0/AppImageKit.pdf |format=pdf |publisher=PortableLinuxApps.org |first=Simon| last=Peter |year=2010 |accessdate=2011-07-29 |title=AppImageKit Documentation 1.0 |pages=2â3|quote=''The AppImage format has been created with specific objectives in mind: Be Simple [...], Maintain binary compatibility [...], Be distribution-agnostic [...], Remove the need for installation [...], Allow to put apps anywhere [...], Do not require recompilation [...], Keep base operating system untouched [...], Do not require root [...]''}} ==See also== *[[Portable application creators]] *[[Autopackage]] *[[RUNZ]], also follows the "one file per application" philosophy *[[Zero Install]], another similar project, does address steps 1-5, but does not follow the "one file per application" philosophy. *[[ROX Desktop|ROX]] uses directories ([[Application directory|AppDirs]]) as application bundles. ==References== == External links == * [http://web.archive.org/web/20070626012138/http://klik.atekon.de/ klik.atekon.de] Official site (archived) ** [http://klik.atekon.de/presentation/ Official presentation] {{Dead link|date=March 2011}} ** [http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-1910211845236337938 Screen capture video of Klik2] * [http://portablelinuxapps.org/ portablelinuxapps.org] Successor project hosted on Source Forge (accessed August 2, 2011) * [http://www.knoppix.net/forum/viewforum.php?f=17 Forum at Knoppix.net] * [http://klik.atekon.de/wiki/index.php/English English articles listed in klik Wiki] {{Dead link|date=February 2010}} * [http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=05/01/15/1815210&tid=90&tid=106 Slashdot -
